column20: Keywords

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column13: Westpac's domestic and family violence leave is uncapped for employees who have experienced domestic or family violence, and carers of those experiencing domestic and family violence can access up to 10 days of leave each year. Temporary emergency accommodation support is also available to employees who are experiencing domestic or family violence.
column20: Violence leave, family violence, emergency accommodation

column6: Parental leave
column13: Care is at the heart of its people proposition and is reflected in its initiatives, benefits and employee programs. This year, Westpac introduced fertility leave, coupled with education initiatives to build awareness of fertility experiences, a peer-led network to provide a safe space to share experiences and access to expert counselling support for fertility and pregnancy loss.
column20: Fertility leave, education initiative, fertility experience

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
column7: If a change involves a reduction of 15 or more FTE positions occupied by permanent employees, Westpac's EA outlines that consultation will be for 10 calendar days. The 10-day calendar requirement does not apply to the direct reports of general managers or above. If, following consultation, an employee is to be retrenched, Westpac will provide the employee with a minimum of 6 weeks' notice (or payment in lieu) following its EA.

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Westpac's performance management framework helps its people and leaders define performance and risk expectations. Over 90% of employees have defined risk goals, and in early FY23, based on FY22 performance, 313 employees received increased variable rewards for delivering exceptional risk outcomes.
column20: Performance management framework, risk expectation, risk outcome

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Westpac's HSW management system includes processes to identify and report hazards, assess risks, and eliminate or control risks in line with the hierarchy of controls to prevent harm to its people. These processes can be routine, such as checklists and inspections completed by employees and leaders or through reporting HSW hazards in Westpac's hazard and incident management system.
column20: HSW management system, hazard, incident management system

column6: Occupational health services
column13: Westpac has a dedicated Employee Care team comprising allied health professionals, safety professionals and psychologists, who provide advice and support on prevention, early intervention and care. Westpac also provides a range of external services for employees, including medical services for employees who may have a work-related injury or illness and an employee assistance program providing free, confidential support and counselling for all Westpac Group employees and their immediate family members.
column20: Employee Care team, health professional, safety professional

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column7: Westpac's consultation procedure defines its approach to consulting with its people on HSW matters and guides more formal consultation arrangements such as health and safety committees and representatives.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: Employees and leaders are trained in Westpac's risk management procedures through its mandatory HSW training, and roles and responsibilities are also articulated in internal HSW policies and procedures. All employees must report HSW hazards and incidents to Westpac's HSW management system. It supports and facilitates leaders investigating the incident and developing and documenting additional controls.\t
column20: HSW training, risk management procedure, HSW policy

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: Westpac provides services and resources to address physical and mental health, such as the employee assistance program and specialised resources to help employees manage their health and well-being. Westpac offers flu and COVID-19 vaccinations through its annual corporate vaccination and workplace and pharmacy partnership programs. In Papua New Guinea and Fiji, Westpac also provides medical insurance to its employees to assist in providing access to healthcare services.
column20: Pharmacy partnership program, mental health, well-being

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: Westpac refreshed its workplace mental health strategy and implemented various initiatives, including piloting a divisional-level mental health risk assessment. The assessment responds to higher expectations from safety regulators to assess and manage workplace mental health risks actively.
column20: Mental health strategy, mental health risk assessment, safety regulator

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Westpac's supplier contracts specify the requirement for suppliers to comply with Westpac's HSW management policies and procedures where services are provided at Westpac premises. The supplier contracts also reinforce the requirement for suppliers to comply with relevant legislation, including WHS laws, in delivering their services.
column20: Supplier contract, supplier, HSW management policy

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column13: Westpac's HSW management system covers all employees, contractors, and suppliers who attend its premises. Westpac's system is internally audited through the HSW assurance review program and externally under its self-insurance licence requirements for workers' compensation.
column20: HSW assurance review, HSW management system, licence requirement

column6: Work-related injuries
Work-related ill health
Average hours of training per year per employee
column7: Westpac's average training hours in 2023 were 24.1 hours per employee.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Over 4,500 leaders participated in Westpac's People Leader Culture Days, a series of CEO-led sessions to reinforce the role of leaders in driving a positive risk culture. The Board, CEO, Group Executives and Senior Leaders shared their insights and facilitated sessions.
column20: People Leader Culture Day, risk culture, CEO

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Westpac implemented various initiatives, including leader-led Purpose Connection sessions and a micro-behavioural nudging 'Skill Boost' campaign, focusing on constructive challenge, admitting mistakes and running effective meetings. In addition, Westpac continued to leverage its 300 culture champion volunteers as role models to drive its purpose, values and behaviours at a local level.
column20: Purpose Connection, Skill Boost, constructive challenge

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
column13: This year, Westpac's people acknowledged over 195,000 moments where their colleagues lived their values and behaviours via its recognition platform. In May 2023, Westpac incorporated active risk management and positive risk behaviours, and since then, almost 34,000 instances of positive risk management behaviour have been recognised.
column20: Recognition platform, risk management, positive risk behaviour

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
column13: The technological, digital and global change rate requires Westpac's people to develop new skills to meet the level of expertise its customers require. Westpac's 'Engineers Make Life Better' campaign improved talent engagement, increasing engineering application numbers by 20%.
column20: Engineers Make Life Better, global change rate, talent engagement

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
column13: Westpac builds ESG capability to support customers transitioning to net zero. Over 470 employees completed online learning in FY23 on human rights, climate and ESG reporting topics. Business Lending partnered with the Australian Graduate School of Management on training to build sustainable business and finance expertise.
column20: ESG training, net zero, human rights

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Westpac measures cultural change through its Voice+ survey, which includes McKinsey's global 'Organisational Health Index' (OHI). The September Voice+ survey outcomes showed progress over the year on all five key behaviours: Simple, Role Clarity, Accountability, Constructive Challenge, and Say it, do it.
column20: Voice+ survey, Organisational Health Index, key behaviour

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: More than 10,000 of Westpac's people are involved in Employee Advocacy Groups, and together, they work to strengthen inclusion. These groups provide a platform for targeted learning and development via mentoring programs such as 'Curious and Wise', which partners with younger and mature employees, shadowing programs to promote cultural diversity and summits for learning and connection.
column20: Employee Advocacy Groups, inclusion, mentoring program

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Cultural representation remains a focus for Westapac. Westpac provides its people with networking, career and leadership opportunities through partnerships with organisations like the Asian Australian Leadership Project. It supports the career progression of individuals with different cultural backgrounds to more senior-level roles.
column20: Asian Australian Leadership Project, cultural representation, cultural background

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column13: Westpac aims to achieve gender pay equity, affirming that equal pay must be given for equal work and experience. Westpac undertakes a remuneration gap analysis annually to identify issues and take steps to investigate and address any pay gaps. Westpac also increased transparency around pay, allowing employees to openly discuss their pay with other employees if they choose to.
column20: Remuneration gap analysis, gender pay equity, transparency

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: Westpac has a zero-tolerance stance on workplace sexual harassment supported by its No Bystander policy, which reminds its people of the obligation to speak up and is reflected in Westpac's Code of Conduct and Sexual Harassment policy.
column20: No Bystander Policy, sexual harassment, Sexual Harassment Policy

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column13: Westpac's Responsible Sourcing Program uses industry and country risk profiles to determine a supplier's inherent risk profile. Westpac mapped its Tier 1 suppliers against these risk profiles to identify and assess its modern slavery risk. Westpac identified 10 high-risk categories, which accounted for $1.61 billion of spending 1, which equated to 22.69% of total spending. Categories may be higher risk due to employment of temporary visa holders, use of low-skilled, child or forced labour, or offshore manufacturing of goods.
column20: Responsible Sourcing Program, inherent risk, supplier

column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column8: Human Rights Position Statement and Action Plan
column13: Westpac's Human Rights Position Statement (HRPS) and Action Plan lays out its commitments and approach to human rights and its position on child safeguarding. It reiterates Westpac's support for the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs), which Westpac is working to incorporate as the foundation of its human rights approach. It details its areas of focus for the next three years.
column20: Human Rights Position Statement and Action Plan, human rights, child safeguarding

column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column13: Westpac followed its Child Safeguarding Position Statement to strengthen the child labour section of its Responsible Sourcing Assessment. Suppliers who respond in the questionnaire that they employ workers under the age of 18 are now assessed to help ensure that child safeguarding policies and procedures are in place and that processes are in place to ensure workers under the age of 18 are not involved in hazardous work.
column20: Child Safeguarding Position Statement, Responsible Sourcing Assessment, hazardous work

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column7: This year, we focused on improving our risk management processes and resulting data quality, including embedding the Sustainability Risk Class and piloting ESG risk assessment tools in institutional, consumer and business credit assessment processes.

column6: Security personnel trained in human rights policies or procedures
column13: This year, Westpac reviewed its risk indicators against modern slavery best practice resources, including those indicators identified as part of a collaboration between the Australian Banking Association (ABA), of which Westpac is a member, and KPMG Australia: Typologies and Indicators of Modern Slavery. It resulted in Westpac adding 57 new indicators to its Modern Slavery Risk Indicator Library, which relate to identifying either victims or perpetrators (those that exploit victims) of modern slavery and are mapped to the different types of modern slavery (i.e. forced labour, human trafficking, debt bondage). The aim is that these indicators will be incorporated into relevant operational processes and be updated as new information arises over time.
column20: Modern Slavery Risk Indicator, Australian Banking Association, victim identification

column6: Incidents of violations involving rights of indigenous peoples
Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column13: In FY22, Westpac began using its digital supplier risk assessment platform to ask suppliers in higher risk categories for modern slavery which country products and services will be manufactured in or delivered from. Westpac will use this data to gain greater insight into location-specific modern slavery risks in its supply chain.
column20: Digital supplier risk assessment platform, supplier, modern slavery

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: Westpac's Customer Advocate provides advice and guidance to its complaints team regarding complaints raised by customers concerning personal banking and small business matters. In addition, the Customer Advocate recommends changes to bank policies, procedures and processes arising from customer complaints and, in particular, focuses on how Westpac can support its vulnerable customers.
column20: Customer Advice, complaint, customer
